reviews.review_text: I certainly understand why many of my friends have trouble getting into this game. If you're coming from Skyrim or Oblivion, you're probably used to having a full set of armor, a decent weapon or spell, knowledge of basic combat, and a fair amount of gold and potions before you even start exploring the world. Morrowind isn't like that. You start the game by stepping off of a boat in a poor swamp town with nothing but the clothes on your back and a rusty iron dagger. There is no fast traveling (or at least no free fast traveling), and the map can sometimes be confusing. The only way you can find what you're looking for sometimes is by reading vague directions your character wrote down in their journal. In Skyrim, Alduin appears before you even have control of your character. In Oblivion, the emperor tells you of Mehrunes Dagon's plot before you leave the first dungeon. In Morrowind, you don't even learn the main plot of the game until you're a few hours into it, and even then you don't have all the information. Many people would consider these things to be negative, or at least intimidating, but in reality I wouldn't have it any other way. If you can get past the dated mechanics and look, I remain convinced that this is the greatest Elder Scrolls game, and my favorite game of all time. The story is wonderful, the lore might possibly be the greatest in all of fiction, the world is wonderfully diverse and detailed, and there is a sense of freedom and magic that makes even games like Skyrim feel constained in comparison. Another incredible thing is that the modding community is still strong 13 years later, meaning that nearly every problem you could have with this game (including the borderline infamous dicerolling) can be fixed. This game is truly a masterpiece and a must play if you are a fan of RPGs. Although your character starts so low, lower than any other RPG I've ever played, the feeling of satisfaction you get when you win is indescribable. You truly feel like a God, and the NPCs treat you the same. There is a reason so many people still rave about this game so many years later, and while it is intimidating, it is without a doubt worth the effort.

Oh, Morrowind. A game where you'll spend countless hours walking through the sprawling foyadas and dreary caves of Vvardenfell. Unlike it's successors, Oblivion and Skyrim, where they bring many of us to worlds that are familiar to us, Morrowind doesn't do that. Instead it brings you to a world unlike any other, the homeland of the Dunmer. From it's lush greens to the west, swampy marshes in the south and east, and deserted and diseased ashlands to the north. The questlines will take you all the way across the massive island, and no doubt will you be spending hours of your time just gazing at the beauty of Morrowind's aesthetics. Granted, it's a game from 2002 and without a doubt the graphics are dated. But with a few mods it will go a long way, and even with Morrowind unmodded, it is still a great game.  As for controls and gameplay, they are by far the clunkiest out of the TES series, and Oblivion shares this characteristic as well. The combat is 'hit by chance' and can get awfully annoying when you die five times to a mudcrab or a cliff racer. The protagonist walks and especially runs awfully slow at the beginning of the game, even with just clothing. My favorite thing, however, is the spells. Something that Skyrim definitely does not have and Oblivion could've been better with was spells and spell making. In Morrowind there is a MASSIVE plethora of spells you can use to create your very own spells, i.e. a spell I made called the Potato-Motato whereas it not only burns an enemy, but paralyzes and poisons it (Needless to say, it's pretty awesome, name aside.).  Although the music is great, the sound effects are... okay. The voice actors seemed to had sounded very bored and that they were just reading their scripts instead of sounding like they're actually their character. The sound effects are pretty much stock sounds you'd find from any game creator program. The stepping noise is awfully annoying and loud, even on lowered volume.  TL;DR It is a great game, and if you are a fan of Oblivion, Skyrim, or both, you NEED to try this game out.

Time to make a wall of text.  Morrowind was not only my second TES game (my first being Oblivion) but it is also personally my favorite. It's sad to see a lot of people be put off from experiencing this game due to things like ♥♥♥ graphics or a less-than stellar combat system. Certainly, the game has it's flaws, but from my perspective it trumps TES IV and V in what it does right. Morrowind is not for the faint of heart who just want to ignore any plot-lines and kill things. The game requires patience and a little bit of creativity to make the most out of it.   Being a mage sucks at first because learning spells is really expensive and magicka is a ♥♥♥♥♥ to manage in this game. Being an archer sucks at first because landing sneak attacks is finicky and whiffing all of your shots due to low agility or fatigue can be VERY frustrating. Even being a warrior sucks since melee combat can be a bit of a slog and heavy armor sucks in the early game.  But the important thing to remember in Morrowind is not to focus in one particular area of expertise, but rather try hard to excel in all of them. Quickly switching weapons and being able to cast spells on the fly makes being a diverse character infinitely easier and more enjoyable. A good warrior is bound to keep a bow around as a ranged weapon and know a spell or two to work themselves out of a difficult situation  But even more interesting than the freedom of character building is the world building of Vvardenfell. The lack of an omnipotent compass and a map that can't warp you around (gasp) make exploring the world to get things done a mandatory step in any player's journey. No spoilers, but the number of things to distract you as you journey across the island are, for the most part, all interesting and only serve to better you as a character and inform you, as the player, of the ever changing world.  TL;DR: This game requires patience, but will lead to a massive payout in story and character growth.

As a later TES fan, you may find it hard to believe that someone who actually started with Skyrim has found Morrowind to be their favorite installment in the series. But the thing is, Morrowind has a particular charm to it, despite it being over eleven years old. There are several things I'd like to discuss about Morrowind and why you should ultimately buy it, whether you're new to the TES series, or are a die-hard fan screaming for nostalgia.  I'd like to create some points with Morrowind discussing its values:  1. Presentation 2. Gameplay 3. Overall  Ready? Let's begin.  Point One: Presentation.  At first glance, Morrowind shows its age with the early Embryo engine with skeletal animation, and an average of 800 x 600 display. Also noticable is how NPC's stay within a general area without eating, drinking, or sleeping (sounds like a serious insomnia epidemic, no?). But besides that, there's nothing really flawed about the graphics, and it's actually reminiscent of Oblivion's. This gives Morrowind a sense of familiarity to begin with. You start off the game with a cinematic intro, as you awaken on an Imperial prison ship that has docked on an Imperial colony, Seyda Neen. From there, you enter your name, choose your race, and once you enter the Commision Office, you are asked to choose your birthsign, favored attributes, and class. From there on, you are asked to deliver a message to a man named Caius, and thus your quest begins. Or at least, the main quest begins. Like other TES games, what you do there on out is up to you. Fight monsters and bandits, loot tombs and ruins, join guilds and political factions, basically what you'd expect from an open-world RPG. That said, the island of Vvardenfell is wonderful, given you can see it, with the render distance and all. Cities aren't closed in separate maps like they were in Oblivion and Skyrim, and the geography is very immersive as you walk around, looking for your objective or simply looking for a dungeon to pillage. As you walk around Vvardenfell, you will encounter strange creatures, such as the Nix-Hound, the Alit, the Netches, and the infamous Cliff Racer. Imagination was really put into these monsters, and some of them won't be so easy to kill. As for the islands residents, Vvardenfell is home to the Dunmer, the ash-skined elves you've seen in the later or earlier installments. Their culture is reminiscent to that of Asian and some tribal cultures, as they may live in the shells of ancient arthropods, adobe buildings, giant mushrooms, and nomadic tents. You will also find your typical Imperial stone structures, things you may yawn about. The in-game literature in Morrowind is very well-written, providing fictional stories to amuse you with, informative tips about the local governments, cities, and religion, and even books that hint on certain gameplay aspects such as vampirism. It truly is something to see the thought lingers in your head.   Point Two: Gameplay  As for perhaps the most important aspect of any game, the gameplay element in Morrowind is quite different from the later installments ( and definitly Arena, but we aren't comparing.) The game offers a wide variety of skills to use, with various weapon types, from typical swords and warhammers, to spears and throwing stars, to crossbows and staves. There are also a wide variety of spells to use, from your average destruction and restoration spells, to teleportation, and even flying spells. Filed Soul Gems can be used on epuipment to enchant them, and an alchemy set can be used with flora, fauna, and even raw minerals to brew potions and poisons. Dialouge with NPCs is somewhat different, though, as they will communicate with text-based responses to the selected topic, and there are many things to talk about with NPCs. The thing about dialouge is despite these many topics, what they say is usually the same as everybody else. Copy-pasted, in fact, thus rendering many NPC void of real personality, unlike Oblivion and Skyrim. As for conflict with enemies, you may either hate it or simply don't care, as it works more like D&D role-playing games. Based on your skil with a certain weapon type, or the Agility attribute itself, you may miss an enemy point-blank while they take crackshots at you (though still able to miss.). Magic works similarly, as using less skilled magic type while tired out will usually result in failure to cast the spell. Aside from those questionable gameplay elements, however, there's still plenty to be had with Morrowind. You can't simply fast travel from the map so you could skip treking all the way to a destination, but rather you use public transportation, teleportation spells, and spells to increase your speed to move around Vvardenfell. Personally, this gave Morrowind a really huge look at the world map, even though it's only 10 square miles + 2-3 from the Bloodmoon expansion and about an additional one from Tribunal, compared to Cyrodill and Skyrim (16 square miles each) or even The Iilic Bay from Daggerfall, with a whopping 480,000 sqare miles (randomly generated though). Plus, you really got to know the geogrophy of Vvardenfell, as the game references landmarks and cities to help you navigate the world, all written in your little journal. Speaking of which, the journal system is probably the closest thing you'll have for a friend in this game ( besides Ahnassi, of course ). Quests and Topics are recorded on your journal with every indication. Viewing your journal is always very helpful if you've been sidetracked from looting dungeons or completing other side quests. That's not to say it isn't flawed, of course. Some quests give really bad direction and can be sometimes misleading. If you don't believe me, join House Redoran. This was really compensated in later installments with a quest marker, as a mere convinence. But don't let the gameplay issues deter you from purchasing this amazing title. Overall, the game function very well and even a late audience can find enjoyment out of it.  Point Three: Overall  Many thing can be said about Morrowind to criticize it. The fact that NPCs had nearly no personality at all, a cumbersome combat and magic system, and even some broken quests do hurt Morrowind a little bit. But despite these cons, Morrowind is uplifted with many pros. Its lore will fascinate you, the landscape will amaze you, and your impact on the game world will really matter here. You truly can be what you want, whether that be a noble knight, a malevolent mage, an infamous assassin, or a troublesome thief, Morrowind can provide.    This game has been Dubb-approved

Ahh Morrowind is so close to home. You play as The Nerevarine as prophesied to defeat the Dagoth Ur, who have tapped into the power of an artefact known as the Heart of Lorkhan in a bid to exert control over the inhabitants of Morrowind. This game is set predominantly on the island of Vvardenfell, just off the coast of Stonefall, in northern Morrowind.  Any hardcore Elder Scrolls fan would instantly feel at home with the rich characterisation, role-playing elements, visual details, soundtrack and the quintessential open-world environment. It is still the best of all the Elder Scrolls games, because of the magnitude of the game for its time and the back-to-basics approach in role-playing - tremendous storyline, realistic characterisation, interaction and progression.  There are weaknesses to this game however, the UI is not particularly helpful to meta-gamers (c.f. Oblivion min-maxing), the journal system whilst improved in the expansion, is still rather cumbersome to navigate, the inherent 'block' in combat can be difficult to get used to for some, as is the one-mouse-button attack and finally the graphics - this is a 2002 game, but thankfully the modding community has made graphic enhancement addons that could be easily installed and used with the game.  Overall, this game is a gem.

Morrowind is something special, something different. Imagine three times the quests and content of Skyrim compressed into one small island, with so much lore and depth that you can lose yourself for hours and hours. Sure, it isn't a really pretty game, but slap MGSO on it and you've got an astonishingly good looking game to complement it's other aspects. You see, in Skyrim you find out you are dragonborn... cool! Yes, that means you get to incinerate people, make them fly off of cliffs etc. In Morrowind though, you start off as almost weaker than mudcrabs, but become a GOD by the end of the game, quite literally. Feel like flying around the whole map without even needing console commands? Go ahead. Want to jump like a super hero from Seyda Neen to Balmora? Do it! Kill the end game boss in one hit? Yes, you can do that. The possibilities are endless, and even though all of the above is true, that doesn't mean you're the strongest thing around, there are still monsters that are quite dangerous even in the late game, see what's different between newer entries and Morrowind? Yes, FREEDOM, to become whatever you like. Now, Morrowind isn't perfect, but it's probably the best game in the series. These days, even though it has aged well enough, it can be very difficult to get into, and since you are thrown instantly into a massive world with only a small dagger, quite confusing. But don't give up. Keep playing, and you could turn your 3 hours of frustration into your 300 hour playthrough of the best game experience you've ever had.  So I don't think I need to tell you how much I recommend this game. But as I said, it's not without flaws, it's simply that the strong points make it so amazing that you won't need to worry about the flaws. I think there is something in this game for everyone, and it's an experience that can't be missed. Grab it in the christmas sale (it's almost always on sale then), grab MGSO, also known as Morrowind Graphics and Sound Overhaul, and make sure your body is ready for one of the best PC games ever made. Have fun!

This game is what Skyrim promises to be. I love all the Bethesda games, even Fallout 4, but there's no denying this is the best Elder Scrolls made IMO. Daggerfall is too archaic for me to want to pick up, and while I recommend the Morrowind Overhaul project, I'm playing through for my first time using only a mod to fix the resolution and loving it.   You can craft spells with EIGHT DIFFERENT EFFECTS. Want a spell mixing multiple elements and area of effect damage? You can do it. Want to summon 8 Daedric Beings with the press of a button? You can do it. Want to create a spell that heals as much as it damages, allowind you to indefinitely practice your magic on one enemy? You. Can. Do. It. All the systems in this game are about as deep as that, and alchemy requires FOUR different machines to properly do it.   The two biggest barriers to entry are the graphics and combat. Morrowind Overhaul fixes that completely so that's squared away. The combat is purely stat based; I do more damage with a mid range sword than the best most OP axe in the game, because you'll miss your swings with a weapon you have no knowledge of how to use. Also WATCH YOUR FATIGUE. % chance you hit is based on how much fatigue you have, don't be like those dumbasses who mash left mouse and wonder why they miss every swing.  Pros-   In depth lore and a wide variety of topics to ask NPCs about.  The best magic system in any game I've played.   Free form quests- I have a sword powered by the soul of a god I slew. Nobody told me to do that, Morrowind merely provides the weapon (Daedric Shortsword) the soul (not gonna spoil which god) and the means (in depth enchanting system) to do it.   Wide variety of locales and quests.   Good storytelling that isn't always spoonfed to you. To cure vampirism without looking it up online, you need to read a couple of books and figure it out yourself. As far as I know, it's impossible any other way besides discovering it by dumb luck or google.  Truly an RPG. Very easy to stick to your characters beliefs, unlike in Skyrim where the story makes you a good guy no matter what you do because you saved the world from Alduin.  Cons-  Somewhat obtuse mechanics. Once they're learned they're badass, but hard to do so. I recommend looking up how to do alchemy, enchanting, etc. as the game expects you to have an instruction manual.  Some bugs. Morrowind Overhaul fixes thousands though.  Personal Preference-   I think having to read to figure stuff out without the game just telling you is awesome. Some might not.  No quest markers. You get directions, and late game are in unexplored areas and have to go off of handwritten maps.   Conclusion-   10/10 best RPG I've ever played. Quite a challenge, but if you're up to it, it's the most rewarding game I've ever played.

I'm going to open with pointing out my bias, because I played and loved this game endlessly on XBox back when it came out.   Objectively, the graphics are very dated, and the gameplay does feel a little clunky. However if you're any fan of more classic RPG's, you need to give this game a look. Before Oblivion's more medieval landscape (Shivering Isles exheunt) and before Skyrim's Canada, Morrowind built a beautiful fantasy landscape, filled with spectacular creatures, varied characters, dwarven mechanations, and original quests.Technically speaking, the sound and graphics aren't much to speak of (though the music is adventurous, and really ups the experience). There is not much voice acting to speak of in most of this game, instead Bethesda opted for text boxes to save space. However, this opens the door for so much lore, and flavor text (which is important, damnit!) that this feels like the best crafted version of the Elder Scrolls universe.   The game isn't levelled like it's predecessors, the world stays as it is, and you start out pretty weak. But it pushes you to be strong, and if you put the time in, you can overcome every challenge. There isn't a lot of emphasis on balance, because like a classic RPG, this game doesn't hold your hand. There isn't a compass to help you find quest points, instead you have a journal which subjectively directs you to your quest goal. For example, 'The cave is north of Seyda Neen, a bit past the bridge on the river.' It feels like a real adventure, going through it.  If I were to price it: 30-Full price due to the age. But the game now can be found for incredibly cheap, I recommend it to anyone who enjoys a hard RPG experience.

The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is a game that was constructed with one of the most developed atmospheres I've seen to this day. Similarly, as the player grows in strength, there is a point at which many of the enemies are fodder rather than a challenge, this takes a while to achieve and is actually feels really rewarding.   While it hasn't necessarily aged well, there are plenty of mods that can bring things up-to-date without to much hassle.   I wouldn't say Morrowind is perfect, especially nowadays, but it still holds a lot of its original charm. If you can get over the first couple humps of difficulty, there's a lot of worthwhile content, characters and environments to explore.

Ah, yes, we've been expecting you. You'll have to be convinced before you officially buy the game. There are a few reasons for you to do this and the choice is yours:  - Deep Story:  From the main quest all the way down to simple side quests, you feel like you are actually making an impact. Most of the quests are not simple fetch quests that tell you to go to X and retrieve Y, with many of them including decision making, puzzle solving, betraying, ect...  - Realistic: About as realistic as you can get when you are involving monsters and magic into the game. One of the first things that comes to mind is the magic system, where you had to think about your use of magicka as not to run out in the middle of combat and have to chug potions or use enchanted items to replenish it. One thing many people didn't enjoy was the rolling to hit, but I did like it and it could be a very good system with some updated animations to be able to show slight shifts of the enemy which causes your blade to hit their armor instead of the Morrowind system where you keep stabbing until you hit. The disposition system more depth to the game, as increasing it may unlock dialog options or allow you to get a reduced price from merchants. Also on disposition, npcs will remember your character, and if you did something they don't agree with (for example morag tong vs thieves guild) they may not discuss certain topics with you, not talk at all with you, or attack you on sight.  - Roleplaying: There are so many ways that you can roleplay your character. Want to be a classic high elf/atronach mage? Done. How about a dark elf thief? Sure. What about a breton warrior? Why not? the choices go on and on as there is no real way to play the game 'wrong' You could meta game and use certain race bonuses to your advantage, like the 'classic' options for class/race combinations, but it is entirely possible to make a stealthy orcish thief, or a powerful redguard mage.   - Advancement:  You start off worse than dirt. You are pushed around by rats and mudcrabs. You are barely able to stab anything with your terrible iron dagger, let alone cast spells. But as you get more experienced, these rats are no longer a challenge, and you move on to ever more dangerous enemies, until you are killing the gods themselves. In Morrowind you really feel you are advancing, especially with mages as they are capable of breaking the game with enchantments and alchemy. But the real fun in Morrowind is not in the beginning, where you are weaker than a mudcrab, but for me it is in the advancement itself. Sure, it is fun to roast all of Balmora with one spell, but the most enjoyable part of the game is in getting powerful. Once you are powerful enough to jump across vvardenfell, while simultaineously raining fireballs with rediculous aoe down on your foes, you are powerful enough to retire, and start as something new.  - Replay Value: Morrowind has tons of replay value, since every game you play you will encounter new npcs, new quests, and new dialog options. Finished as a fighter character after joining house redoran and fighting your way up the ranks in the fighters guild? Try a thief who joins house hlaalu and the morag tong. With the ammount of guilds and quests in this game you will never finish every single one of them. It would be hard to fill in the entire map, let alone finish all the quests. But if you are getting bored of doing the same guild quests and main quest again, that is when you can get mods. Morrowind rebirth adds an entire new area full of npcs, and more importantly quests, for you to explore.  Interesting. Before you purchase the game make sure this information is correct:  - Summing Up:  Morrowind is a deep, rich rpg where you actually have an impact on the world. It is about as realistic as it could get with what it includes. Advancement feels meaningful and deserved. There are many options for roleplaying, as well as tons of replay value. First of all, I want to say that nostalgia was not a factor in this review, seeing as I played it for the first time less than a year ago. That being said, here is my review:   This game is a masterpiece. It is the most in-depth, and most immersive, RPG of all time. While I love all of the Elder Scrolls games, this one is a step above the others. There is much more to do, and it gives you more freedom than any other games in the series. Morrowind felt like a living, breathing, world that you were actually inside. This being a Bethesda game, it is extremely buggy though, which can kill immersion. The world feels endless, and there is no way you will see every place, and do every quest, in less than 3000 hours. 100 hours in, 90% of your map will still be unexplored. Morrowind is the only Elder Scrolls game that lets you do things like make your own spells, leading to the craziest outcomes that no other player has ever seen. Sure the graphics and sound are outdated, and the combat is annoying at first, but that isn't the point. Morrowind will make you feel like you visiting another planet, and lets you become whoever you want. Unlike in Skyrim, where you are the chosen one with a destiny to kill Alduin, in Morrowind you are an ordinary person. There is nothing special about you, you don't have a 'destiny' to do anything, and you are a foreigner that everyone looks down upon at first. As you play though, you will gain reputation, either good or bad. This depends on how you play the game, and will effect your entire experience. Morrowind is huge compared to Cyrodil or Skyrim, and I'm not saying that because of the lack of fast travel (which I don't think was a really a good or bad thing in later installments, just a different experience). The soundtrack, though small, completely fits the game and remains one of my favorites. There are flaws in this game though (other than the ones I have already mentioned). The dialogue is terrible, (though more immersive) the journal system was confusing, the leveling system can easily be exploited, the dungeons are dull, and some of the AI is really dumb. Overall though, the games strengths easily make up for all the faults. Morrowind is the perfect game for anyone that likes open world RPGs. 9.8/10

The world is filled with people you can interact with, and so many of these can offer you quests to keep you busy instead of mindlessly roaming the countryside.  At some point you should take on the main quest, which is a fantastic story in of itself. This game is so deep and interesting, and has the entire Elder Scrolls mythology fuelling it every step of the way. Sure, it's 99% reading text instead of actual hearing the NPC's talking, but this is how they have managed to cram so much backstory into this game. Add the amazing soundtrack and you have an immense experience, where you feel just like the lonely outlander the peoples of Morrowind refer to you as.

The quintessential Elder Scrolls experience. Forget Oblivion and forget Skyrim, pick up any of the HD packs for Morrowind and some other essentials like a journal mod, the seamless bodies mod and a good homebase and you're set for playing the best Elder Scrolls game to date.  The story is decently long and progressive. The game plays like a CRPG, so you need to immerse yourself in the world to play it, no quest markers and no extensive journal support. Tag-based conversations and limitless exploration without loading screens means you'll really need, and by the end of it, really enjoy, the freedom the game gives you. The only thing it does alert you for is if you kill a vital quest NPC, but aside from that, you have free reign. You need to remember names, you need to learn locations and generally get a good feel for the world.. and that's a good thing.  You won't be chasing markers on the map like a cat chasing a laser pointer, you'll actually be surprised by that daedric ruin or hidden dungeon. You'll need to learn to move around using fragmented fast travel. Yes you can fast travel, but considering the multiple options of transportation, it's like moving around the city using bus/tram/walking to get from point A to point B. Minus certain spells, you will need to learn the transportation 'map' of the game. To note, the map size isn't gargantuan, but it doens't need to be, and areas are rarely placed for filler.  A note of warning regarding the gameplay though, it is dice based, not physical based. So if you hit an enemy with a weapon, unless you hear the 'clink' of hitting and the damage applying, you missed, and when you start out, you'll be missing a lot. Spells hit all the time if they hit though so take that into consideration. Aside from these mentions, the rest is best left to be learned.   This is as much an RPG as a survival game when you start out. From petty freshly-released prisoner to walking demigod, you will actually feel the character getting stronger, and you'll know it will be because you chose to made him stronger, not because of you just ate food off a plate prepared for you.    Closing up, if you're coming into the series from Oblivion, or worse, Skyrim, you'll replace that ocean with the depth of a drop with a lake, indeed, but one you could sink in for days instead of just dipping your toes in for a few minutes.

Okay, so the first thing you need to know about Morrowind is that it is an old game from that classic era of PC gaming where the solution to most interface problems was 'let's add more menus'. The controls are clunky, the running speed is unbearably slow and the graphics are outdated. But that doesn't matter because you can change all of that with a combination of console commands, mods and good old fashion THIS GAME IS GREAT.  Story is the absolute best of any Elder Scrolls game in my opinion. The world is the coolest, and even though it's older, it's still absolutely huge. Your goal in this game, you ask? Oh, well you're just going to become the REINCARNATION OF A GOD. WITH GOD POWERS. YOU BECOME IMMORTAL. That is way cooler than stopping some gods from invading Cyrodil or killing a few dragons, seriously. You also get to meet the only Dwemer still alive (that we know of), which is pretty cool too. The expansions are very good--not Shivering Isles level of hype but still respectable in their own rights. Bloodmoon adds werewolves and Solstheim, which you may know from Skyrim, and Tribunal adds addition content after you complete the game.  If you're coming from Skyrim or Oblivion, Morrowind...isn't like that. At all. Imagine the racism of Skyrim combined with the actual RPG elements of Oblivion and you'll get somewhere close to where Morrowind is on the spectrum. It's tough to get into when you're coming from the moden era of gaming, and Morrowind desperately needs a remake just so that the newer generation can understand it's hype. Hell, if they were coming out with an official Morrowind remake, I would be the first in line. Check out Skywind in the meantime, and while you're at it, buy Morrowind because it's on sale all the time, because it's one of the best classic RPGs of all time, because the story is absolutely beautiful and the world is consistent...buy it. Just buy it. You won't regret it.

What can I say? The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is one of the greatest RPGs ever made, from arguably the greatest RPG series ever made. It's vast, and it feels like it never ends. The many hours you spend playing weave together an incredibly detailed and enriching story that is part of a much larger cosmology that connects and encompasses the entire Elder Scrolls series. You can spend hours just reading the in-game books alone. If you are even remotely interested in role-playing or adventure games, then this is a must-have, as well as its descendents, Oblivion and Skyrim (as of 2013).  For those who are more familiar with Oblivion or Skyrim, this is a more difficult game with a much steeper learning curve. Your character will move slowly at first, will run out of fatigue very quickly (unlike in Skyrim, fatigue is depleted by running and is much more of a factor in how successful all your actions will be), and you will be unable to carry or store much loot. It will take a while to level up and increase your skills at first, but be patient, and you will soon notice that things really do get easier.  Morrowind also seems considerably longer than either Oblivion or Skyrim, because there are many more factions you can join, and each has several questgivers (assuming you want more than just the main quest, which is also lengthy). The other thing you need to know is that there is NO fast-travel in this game. Be prepared to spend a lot of time traveling on foot. But these things just add to the challenge and depth of this classic game. When given a dungeon to explore, you won't get a convenient arrow pointing you to the exact location; often, you'll just be told 'it's southwest from X' and it's up to you to find it. This adds to the realism and the immersion.  As if the vanilla game weren't enough, there are two expansion packs included in the GOTY edition that are bound to add many enjoyable hours to your experience, as well as tons of free mods out there to spice things up. The price you pay for this game is nothing compared to the months or years of solid, fun role-playing it provides.

A Convoluted Introduction to Morrowind:  Indeed, Morrowind as a whole is quite possibly the most fundamentally flawed game ever, yet this leads to it's intrinsic realism. The odd hipocrasies one will find within, equally mirrors reality in all it's many forms - From Dagoth Ur and the N'wahs to the irreplacable beauty of Telvanni Towers, it is a story mirred in reality in as much fiction.  With Morrowind, no matter ones class, caste, origin, or any other determining factor, one is merely a person. How absolutely profound. One is not God. One is not destined for greatness or glory, someone merely is. The world itself exists, and the person who choses it, exists within. There is no endless prophecy that one is required to fill, and indeed the prophecy that does exist, can be fulfilled by mistake - the world itself questions which path is correct and rewards erring.  As a person within this world, you will find many things mundane, yet inexplicably exciting. The scenery is gorgeous and filled with meaning under every stone. This world is slow, and sleepy - yet homey, and comfortable not unlike one's bed. Indeed, search any house in the game and find how lovingly things were placed, with intent - candles, pillows, books, and pots, all carefully placed by the inhabitiants. The people who live within this world can often be as hostile as they are pleasant, and as you make friends and influence enemies, you will find your story has unfolded quite unlike any other - as a thief, mage, fighter, Poet-Warrior or otherwise, where the small successes of many failures will reward you with a level of satisfaction quite unlike any other. This world rewards those with perserverance and time, punishing those who rush and come unprepared without Kagrenac's tools, again the most important of which is time.  Morrowind is a game and world that demands only time. Not attention, nor thought, nor really any clever wit; merely time to experience and enjoy even when void of understanding. The real tools of this game are patience for it's mechanics, it's loveable and maddening quirks, but more importantly it's infinite flaws that are indeed features of life within. Approach it with an open mind, and time to spare, and Morrowind will show you a world in strife with lasting peace on it's horizon. Who will you be? Or more interestingly; will you even choose to be? This is the question Morrowind will ask of you. Do you wish to be God, like the Tribunal? Do you wish merely to exist and experience the world as it was crafted, living within? Or perhaps the secrets of Divine must be uncovered; where the alternate possibilites of truth are found - where in the story becomes deeper and more divided, a truth crafted only by your belief or disbelief of it.  If you have a love of knowledge, of life, of lore - Morrowind reflects it with the detailed books and believable religions that anchor it to reality; though of course in a metaphorical sense, as surely Sharmat is not the devil incarnate, nor is Vehk abhrahemic.   Morrowind is as much reality as we choose it to be; for those in doubt one must simply consult the concepts of CHIM and CODA. Surely it's all in good fun, however these concepts will enable an appreciation of Morrowind far beyond the basic and mundane levels most enjoy. These concepts are what make the concept of a Dragon-Break, as much reality as we chose them to be. The lore is rich and fluid beyond anyone's wildest imaginings, and indeed the concepts it present make it almost seem as though it were a dream realized only by us, the inhabitants who choose it to be realize, or deny it life.  Without a doubt, the most comprehensive, satisfyingly maddeningly difficultly easy game ever meticulously crafted by the hands of men and surely a gift of the Godhead above. I recommend Morrowind only if the game and both DLC don't set you back more than $10, and you are a massive Elder Scrolls/open-world fan.  Morrowind has been lauded as the best game of the TES series by some. I started with Skyrim, which is my favorite game of all time, then played Oblivion, Morrowind and a bit of ESO. Morrowind is, in THIS series #2 in my opinion, and Oblivion was shockingly bad for me. Expect nothing and you will have fun.  Morrowind is old now. I remember when the game “Pong” was new and how awesome Space Invaders was when it came out but that doesn't mean I still play them now. Morrowind's graphics are archaic, and the landscape is rather empty and a bit “angular”. On the other hand, I like the theme and the visual aesthetic – especially the architecture. I also like the concept behind the main quest, but after playing newer games, the quests leading you into the story don't build interest or motivation to continue. Granted, I'm used to faster-paced, modern games, but the side quests feel like mere time killing devices that provide time to get stronger before the end.   NPC are horrifyingly random and lifeless. Important dialog is written, so npc only speak only random, ambient lines. Everyone in the game, from nobles, to guards, to beggars, keeps saying over and over 'I could kill that Guar (type of beast). Those boots are ruined.' No dialog at all would have been better. The written dialog options were okay, but even after a quest is completed, you'll have the old dialog options littering up the dialog window, so finding the options you actually need is frustrating. You may as well not talk to anyone at all and use Google to navigate through your quests.  Morrowind combat is nothing like more recent Bethesda games. It's based on the roll of a die; not the player's actual gaming skill. In a word, it's rubbish key-smashing until you kill something or run out of potions and die. I will go so far as to say that such a combat system never belonged in a video game at all. I didn't expect I'd be buying the Elder Scrolls version of D&D.  Magic using is brutal...just an awful, horribly painful system. Magicka does not regenerate without sleeping long enough to recover it, and your pool of magicka is very limited. Perhaps by the end of the game you'll have built up a big enough magicka pool to use your spells, but by then...who cares? The only way to play as a mage is to cheat with mods that regenerate your magicka... or to spend days trying and failing to make magicka potions. It's clear that magic was made to be used as a backup to other forms of combat or...running away?  I have many complaints about this game, but the theme, open-world, and game aesthetic are strong. With a ton of mods Morrowind is enjoyable for a few hours at a time. Just wait until it's on sale.

Vvardenfell Morrowind throws you (the Outlander) into the alien setting of Vvardenfell, an island in the North East of Morrowind. Part of the joy of Morrowind is the exploration of the game ; its a truly open world that doesn't feel like its empty.  The Outlander When you arrive in Seyda Need in the first five minutes of the game, you're scum. You're filth in the eyes of the citizens. However, as you progress, your impact will be felt by many. NPCs may reference an impact of one of your actions in a quest. You feel like you're actually a part of the world. Your decisions matter as opposed to those of other games. You feel like you're progressing (there is so level scaling so you're actually becoming stronger and not being made to fight enemies at the same level as you). Morrowind is the 2002 RPG brought by Bethesda, touted to a cult-classic status. Over the years, as ever more casual sequels with ever more cut aspects have released, Morrowind (and to a lesser extent Daggerfall) has been hailed as the pinnacle of the series by a famously rabid following.  I didn't play Morrowind with any mods, so this review is of the completely vanilla, raw version published by Bethesda on Steam. Also the first playthrough, so no real benefit of 'nostalgia goggles' going on here.  Two aspects really carry Morrowind - the art style and lore.   Morrowind's art style is beyond fantastic - this game, even in its vanilla state, has some of the most interesting locales in any RPG to date, and despite technological restraints managed to bring the raw original brilliance of the artwork behind it to fruition. Dozens of hours into the game I was still getting surprised by fascinating structures and brilliant armour designs (moving past the giant pauldrons of the era). It's impossibly not to appreciate the locales in a genre dominated by generic and uninteresting art directions (they addressed this in the sequels).  Every bit of lore from this game is some of the most engaging I've read - and from its recognizable roots as another Tolkien-esque fantasy scape, has managed to conjure something not only fantastic on its own merit, but some of the best backstory that exists to date. From stories of politics to gods to simple farmers in over their heads, Vvardenfell leave you actively involved in its world on every level, even if initiating reading passages from the UI is a bit of a chore.  The UI itself is reminiscent of System Shock 2's responsive and novel system, Morrowind's one-button activated menu system makes shifting through the various systems outright fun. Small touches, like letting you have a rather hefty amount of customization on your own menu layout, make what would otherwise be a chore into it's own miniature slice of fun. The air of the game wanting you to customize it to your heart's content permeates it - from the famous amount of armour slots to the massive skill system, all of it which has survived the passing of time intact.  One of the big debates when discussing any earlier game is whether or not it 'aged well'. I'm of the opinion that good games don't age well - either they were always good, or we were simply making do. On that note, it's hard to argue that we weren't just 'making do' with the attempts at naturalism in Morrowind. Walking animations and most of the animations are jank and laughable, vast landscapes cartoonish and graphics that were cutting edge for the time look rusty to say the least.  But as a game? Far from making do, Morrowind was just never particularly good.   Combat is braindead. Any combination of stealth, brute force or guile-driven magics - while all expansive systems in themselves - is a mouse-clicking mind-numbing stat-check fest that never grows in complexity or demand, and reaches the maximum amount of brainpower needed 5 minutes into the game. It's a turn-based game that masquerades as a realtime game, with none of the strategic elements and spacing that turn-based and tabletop games naturally have.   Add to that the sheer amount of vapid filler content in this game and you've got a recipe for a game that squanders its excellent foundations. For every decent Main Quest or DLC slice of content, there's twenty times that amount in repetitive commute, escort/fetch quests, and three-room dungeons littered across the landscape. It reduces this fantastic looking game into committing the greatest sin a game can: it gets boring.   From beginning to end you'll be doing the same thing, doing the same dressed up quests, and the broken Fortify Attribute systems or decent DLC/Main Quest content don't save it in a world where Ultima exists, doing the same things but not relying on quantity over quality.  On top of this, the fantastic lore just leaves you wanting more. That you never see silt-striders crossing the swamps, or the cult-hags conspiring for the sake of conspiring, or any of the lively world painted by the ingame lore just leaves the world feeling incredibly static, lifeless, restrictive, and honestly disappointing. A picture paints a thousand words, but Morrowind came jam-packed with a novel's worth of imaginative writing.  Now most of these concerns can actually be modded out. The graphics replaced (though not always with the original concept art in mind, sadly), the combat more demanding, the dungeons more fun - but here's the kicker, the Steam version is completely unmoddable without practically divorcing it from Steam.  The GOTY Steam version doesn't even offer resolutions beyond 4:3, even though they took the time to update the logo! I can see myself returning to this game. But not in its current state, not without even being able to address the caveats it has without breaking the one reason to buy it on Steam to begin with.  There's no reason to buy this version of Morrowind. What's here worth experiencing isn't worth experiencing here - move on, and acquire it by other means if you really intend to see what people are raving about.

The combat system is much worse than I had thought. I cannot imagine wanting to do more such fights with lots of dull mouse-clicking and key-pressing just to make my hero do something. Else he would stand like frozen and be torn into pieces. He would not even try to defend himself automatically, such as to raise a shield in defense. So I give different moves a try, retreating as evasive maneuver, moving forward as a thrusting attack, moving sideways and clicking to swing the weapon. It sounds entertaining at first, but there is no feedback at all on whether this will help my hero in any way. I guess it doesn't. It only affects the type of damage when hitting the target. But I don't even know the enemy's resistances, if any. Everything I do during combat, I don't know whether it will be good practice. Same for the enemies. I don't learn how they attack me except or any animation. If my hero gets paralyzed temporarily, no feedback at all about how long it will take before mouse-clicks or keyboard will work again for an own attack.  The 3D world may be large and filled with many quests. This opens opportunities. Observing somebody at night from the top of a lighthouse tower, nice idea. Beyond that, at the start of the game in the first city and the second largest city of the world, I feel alone, and there is way too much to read about the world, the cities, the various fractions, plus the many items. Various people, such as commoners, have not much else to say than to tell the same or another bit about the world. In a user-interface that makes it tedious to look up all their answers. I find books inside the game, which may or may not be relevant. I start as an outsider with a first duty. I try two ways to reach the target city. The fast one, and the tiresome one by walking or running slowly a looooong way. Somewhere near a lake, I rest outside. An assassin attacks me. I kill him, but due to the chaotic nature of the action-centric combat, I cannot tell whether it has been helpful to summon a skeleton. Too late or early enough? No idea. If not my hero, did I gain any experience at least? I dunno. Perhaps it's necessary to spend hundreds of hours reading Wiki pages and to retry the same encounter several times.  Motivation dropped further upon starting the next few 'duties'. Collecting mushrooms and flowers, buying a bowl. No, thanks. The only alternative seems to be to wander around and maintain a personal Wiki.
